titleStmt.title: A Serious Poem upon William Wood, Brazier,

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: printed in Ireland, 1724.
This was made upon Mr Woods obtaining a Patent to coyn Copper halfpence in Ireland, wch 08. proved much under the true Value.
When Foes are o'ercome We preserve them from Slaughter,
To be Hewers of Wood and Drawers of Water;
Now altho' to draw water is not very good,
Yet We all should rejoyce to be Hewers of Wood.
I own it hath often provokd me to mutter,
That a rogue so obscure should make such a Clutter:
But ancient Philosophers wisely remark,
That old rotten Wood will shine in the dark.
The Heathens we read had Gods made of Wood,
Who could do 'em no harm, if they did 'em no good,
But this Idol Wood may do Us great evill,
Their Gods were of Wood, but our Wood is the Devill.
To cutt down fine Wood is a very bad thing,
And yet We all know much Gold it will bring,
Then if cutting down Wood brings money good store,
Our money to keep lett us Cutt down one more.Now hear an old Tale: There anciently stood
(I forgett in what Church) an Image of Wood,
Concerning this Image there went a prediction,
It would burn a whole Forrest; nor was it a Fiction,
'Twas cutt into faggots, and putt to the flame,
To burn an old Fryar One Forrest by name,
My Tale is a wise one, if well understood,
Find You but the Fryar, and I'le find the Wood.I hear among schollars there is a great doubt,
From what kind of tree this Wood was hewn out;
Teague made a good pun, by a brogue in his speech,
And said, By my shoul he's the Son of a Beech;
Some call him a Thorn, the curse of a Nation,
As thorns were designd to be from the Creation;
Some think him cutt out from the poisonous Yew,
Beneath whose ill shade no plant ever grew;
Some say he's a Birch, a thought very odd,
For none but a Dunce would come under his Rod:
But I'll tell you the Secret, & pray do not blab,
He is an old Stump cutt out of a Crab,
And England has putt this Crab to a hard use,
To cudgell Our bones, & for drink give us Verjuice;
And therefore his Witnesses justly may boast,
That none are more properly Knights of the Post.I ne're could indure my Talent to Smother,
I told you our Tale, I'le tell you another;
A Joyner, to fasten a Saint in a nitch,
Bor'd a large Augerhole in the Images breech,
But finding the Statue to make no complaint,
He would ne'er be convinc'd it was a true Saint:
When the true Wood arrives, as he soon will no doubt,
(For thats but a 1Woods Effigies was carryd about & burnt. Sham Wood they carry about)
What Stuff he is made on you quickly may find,
If you make the same tryal, and bore him behind,
I'll hold you a groat, when you wimble his bum
He'l bellow as loud as the De'il in a drum.
From me I declare you shall have no denyal,
For there can be no harm in making a Tryal,
And when to the joy of Your hearts he has roar'd,
You may shew him about for a new Groaning Board.Hear one Story more; and then I will stop,
I dream't, Wood was told he should dye by a Drop,
So methought he resolv'd no liquor to taste,
For fear the first Drop might as well be his last;
But dreams are like Oracles, 'its hard to explain 'em,
For it provd that he dy'd by a Drop at Kilmainham;2Their Tyburn or place of Execution.
I wakd' wtḥ delight, and not without hope,
Very soon to see Wood drop down from a Rope.
How he, and how We at each other should grin!
Tis kindness to hold a Friend up by the Chin.
But soft, says the Herald, I cannot agree,
For Metall on Metall is false Heraldry,
Why that may be true, yet Wood upon Wood
Ile maintain wtḥ my Life is Heraldry good.334-174F
